enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is the architecture of the Transformer model?
What are the main components of the Transformer model?
How is the encoder structured in the Transformer model?
What are the sub-layers in each encoder layer?
How is the decoder structured in the Transformer model?
What are the sub-layers in each decoder layer?
What is the dimension of the outputs produced by the sub-layers and embedding layers?
How many identical layers are in the encoder and decoder stacks?
What is the role of residual connections and layer normalization in the model?
How does the decoder handle predictions for a given position?
What is the purpose of masking in the self-attention sub-layer of the decoder?
What are the final layers that produce the output probabilities?
What does Figure 1 illustrate?

SUMMARY: The document describes the architecture of the Transformer model, as depicted in Figure 1. The model consists of an encoder and a decoder, each composed of a stack of N = 6 identical layers.

The encoder's layers each have two sub-layers: a multi-head self-attention mechanism and a position-wise fully connected feed-forward network.

The decoder's layers have three sub-layers: a masked multi-head self-attention sub-layer, a multi-head attention sub-layer that attends over the encoder's output, and a position-wise fully connected feed-forward network. The self-attention sub-layer in the decoder is modified with masking to prevent positions from attending to subsequent positions, ensuring predictions for position 'i' only depend on outputs at positions less than 'i'. This is combined with the output embeddings being offset by one position.

Both the encoder and decoder employ residual connections around each sub-layer, followed by layer normalization. The output of each sub-layer is defined as LayerNorm(x + Sublayer(x)). To facilitate these residual connections, all sub-layers and embedding layers in the model produce outputs of dimension dmodel = 512.

The model architecture starts with input and output embeddings, which are combined with positional encodings. The final output of the decoder stack is fed into a linear layer and a softmax layer to generate output probabilities.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: Figure 1 provides a detailed diagram of the Transformer model architecture, which is divided into two main components: the encoder on the left and the decoder on the right.

The encoder side shows the flow starting from "Inputs" which go into an "Input Embedding" layer, followed by the addition of "Positional Encoding". This combined embedding is then fed into a stack of N layers (indicated by "Nx"). Each layer in this stack consists of a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer followed by an "Add & Norm" step, and then a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, also followed by an "Add & Norm" step.

The decoder side starts with "Outputs (shifted right)" that go into an "Output Embedding" layer and also have "Positional Encoding" added. This is then fed into a similar stack of N layers. Each decoder layer has three sub-layers. The first is a "Masked Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer, followed by "Add & Norm". The second is a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer that takes inputs from the encoder stack's output and the output of the previous decoder sub-layer, which is also followed by "Add & Norm". The third is a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, again followed by "Add & Norm".

The final output from the decoder stack is passed through a "Linear" layer and then a "Softmax" layer to produce the "Output Probabilities". The diagram clearly illustrates the residual connections around each sub-layer, which are then normalized (Add & Norm).

Figure 1: The Transformer - model architecture.

wise fully connected feed-forward network. We employ a residual connection [10] around each of the two sub-layers, followed by layer normalization [1]. That is, the output of each sub-layer is LayerNorm(x + Sublayer(x)), where Sublayer(x) is the function implemented by the sub-layer itself. To facilitate these residual connections, all sub-layers in the model, as well as the embedding layers, produce outputs of dimension dmodel = 512.

Decoder: The decoder is also composed of a stack of N = 6 identical layers. In addition to the two sub-layers in each encoder layer, the decoder inserts a third sub-layer, which performs multi-head attention over the output of the encoder stack. Similar to the encoder, we employ residual connections around each of the sub-layers, followed by layer normalization. We also modify the self-attention sub-layer in the decoder stack to prevent positions from attending to subsequent positions. This masking, combined with fact that the output embeddings are offset by one position, ensures that the predictions for position i can depend only on the known outputs at positions less than i.

Figure 1 provides a detailed diagram of the Transformer model architecture, which is divided into two main components: the encoder on the left and the decoder on the right.

The encoder side shows the flow starting from "Inputs" which go into an "Input Embedding" layer, followed by the addition of "Positional Encoding". This combined embedding is then fed into a stack of N layers (indicated by "Nx"). Each layer in this stack consists of a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer followed by an "Add & Norm" step, and then a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, also followed by an "Add & Norm" step.

The decoder side starts with "Outputs (shifted right)" that go into an "Output Embedding" layer and also have "Positional Encoding" added. This is then fed into a similar stack of N layers. Each decoder layer has three sub-layers. The first is a "Masked Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer, followed by "Add & Norm". The second is a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer that takes inputs from the encoder stack's output and the output of the previous decoder sub-layer, which is also followed by "Add & Norm". The third is a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, again followed by "Add & Norm".

The final output from the decoder stack is passed through a "Linear" layer and then a "Softmax" layer to produce the "Output Probabilities". The diagram clearly illustrates the residual connections around each sub-layer, which are then normalized (Add & Norm).

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is an attention function?
How is the output of an attention function computed?
What are the components of an attention function, and what form do they take?
How is the weight assigned to each value calculated in an attention function?

SUMMARY: An attention function maps a query and a set of key-value pairs to an output. The query, keys, values, and output are all vectors. The output is a weighted sum of the values, and the weight for each value is determined by a compatibility function between the query and the corresponding key.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS IMAGE***

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2 Attention

An attention function can be described as mapping a query and a set of key-value pairs to an output, where the query, keys, values, and output are all vectors. The output is computed as a weighted sum of the values, where the weight assigned to each value is computed by a compatibility function of the query with the corresponding key.

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is "Scaled Dot-Product Attention"? What are the inputs for Scaled Dot-Product Attention? What are the dimensions of the queries, keys, and values? How do you compute the dot products of the query with all keys? What is the formula for the attention function? What are the two most commonly used attention functions? What is the difference between dot-product attention and Scaled Dot-Product Attention? Why is dot-product attention faster and more space-efficient in practice than additive attention? What happens when dot-product attention is used for large values of dk without scaling? Why are the dot products scaled by 1/√dk? What is Multi-Head Attention?

SUMMARY: This document describes "Scaled Dot-Product Attention". The inputs for this function are queries (Q) and keys (K) of dimension dk, and values (V) of dimension dv. The process involves computing the dot products of the query with all keys, dividing each by √dk, and then applying a softmax function to get the weights on the values. The attention function is computed on a set of queries, keys, and values packed into matrices Q, K, and V. The formula to compute the matrix of outputs is: Attention(Q, K, V) = softmax(QKT / √dk)V. The two most common attention functions are additive attention and dot-product (multiplicative) attention. Scaled Dot-Product Attention is identical to dot-product attention but includes a scaling factor of 1/√dk. Dot-product attention is significantly faster and more space-efficient because it can be implemented with highly optimized matrix multiplication. For larger values of dk, additive attention performs better than unscaled dot-product attention because large dot products can push the softmax function into regions with very small gradients. To counteract this, the dot products are scaled by 1/√dk. Figure 2 visually represents Scaled Dot-Product Attention and Multi-Head Attention, which is composed of several parallel attention layers.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: Figure 2 contains two diagrams. The left diagram illustrates "Scaled Dot-Product Attention". It shows a flowchart where inputs Q (queries) and K (keys) undergo a matrix multiplication (MatMul). The result is then scaled, optionally masked, and passed through a SoftMax function. This output is then matrix multiplied with the input V (values) to produce the final output. The right diagram illustrates "Multi-Head Attention". It shows inputs V, K, and Q being fed into several parallel "Scaled Dot-Product Attention" layers. The outputs from these layers are concatenated and then passed through a final linear layer. The caption states: "(left) Scaled Dot-Product Attention. (right) Multi-Head Attention consists of several attention layers running in parallel."

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2.1 Scaled Dot-Product Attention

We call our particular attention "Scaled Dot-Product Attention" (Figure 2). The input consists of queries and keys of dimension dk, and values of dimension dv. We compute the dot products of the

3

Scaled Dot-Product Attention

Multi-Head Attention

Linear

Figure 2: (left) Scaled Dot-Product Attention. (right) Multi-Head Attention consists of several attention layers running in parallel.

√

query with all keys, divide each by dk, and apply a softmax function to obtain the weights on the values.

In practice, we compute the attention function on a set of queries simultaneously, packed together into a matrix Q. The keys and values are also packed together into matrices K and V . We compute the matrix of outputs as:

Attention(Q,K,V ) = softmax( QKT √ dk )V (1)

The two most commonly used attention functions are additive attention [2], and dot-product (multi- plicative) attention. Dot-product attention is identical to our algorithm, except for the scaling factor 1√ of . Additive attention computes the compatibility function using a feed-forward network with dk a single hidden layer. While the two are similar in theoretical complexity, dot-product attention is much faster and more space-efﬁcient in practice, since it can be implemented using highly optimized matrix multiplication code.

While for small values of dk the two mechanisms perform similarly, additive attention outperforms dot product attention without scaling for larger values of dk [3]. We suspect that for large values of dk, the dot products grow large in magnitude, pushing the softmax function into regions where it has extremely small gradients 4. To counteract this effect, we scale the dot products by 1√ . dk

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is Multi-Head Attention?
How does Multi-Head Attention work?
What is the benefit of Multi-Head Attention?
Why do the dot products get large in the attention mechanism?
What are the dimensions of the learned linear projections for queries, keys, and values?

SUMMARY: Instead of a single attention function, Multi-Head Attention uses multiple learned linear projections. The queries, keys, and values are projected h times to dimensions dk, dk, and dv, respectively. The attention function is then performed in parallel on each of these projected versions. The resulting dv-dimensional output values are concatenated and projected again to produce the final values. This process is depicted in Figure 2. The main advantage of multi-head attention is that it allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions, which is inhibited by the averaging in a single attention head. To illustrate why dot products can get large, if the components of q and k are independent random variables with a mean of 0 and a variance of 1, their dot product has a mean of 0 and a variance of dx.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS IMAGE***

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2.2 Multi-Head Attention

Instead of performing a single attention function with dmodel-dimensional keys, values and queries, we found it beneﬁcial to linearly project the queries, keys and values h times with different, learned linear projections to dk, dk and dv dimensions, respectively. On each of these projected versions of queries, keys and values we then perform the attention function in parallel, yielding dv-dimensional output values. These are concatenated and once again projected, resulting in the ﬁnal values, as depicted in Figure 2.

Multi-head attention allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions. With a single attention head, averaging inhibits this.

‘To illustrate why the dot products get large, assume that the components of q and k are independent random variables with mean 0 and variance 1. Then their dot product, g -k = ves, qiki, has mean 0 and variance dx.

The queries, keys, and values are projected h times to dimensions dk, dk, and dv, respectively. The attention function is then performed in parallel on each of these projected versions. The resulting dv-dimensional output values are concatenated and projected again to produce the final values. This process is depicted in Figure 2. The main advantage of multi-head attention is that it allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions, which is inhibited by the averaging in a single attention head. To illustrate why dot products can get large, if the components of q and k are independent random variables with a mean of 0 and a variance of 1, their dot product has a mean of 0 and a variance of dx.
